"Harakiri" is a sophisticated film that critiques the Samurai of the Tokugawa era around 1630. The order in which this story is told is crucially important to the way the viewer perceives each character on an individual basis. Although the film starts with a Ronin desiring to commit Harakiri, known as Hanshiro, it quickly turns into a flashback when counselor Saito tells the story of a man named Motome Chijiwa. The story reveals how Motome dies, but is irrelevant until Hanshiro tells his life story just before he is about to commit Harakiri. After hearing Hanshiro's detailed story, the camera angles and placement begin to play a key role in the message behind this film. Not only does it become clear that Hanshiro is at the Iyi temple with a hidden agenda, but we also start to see close up shots of Saito who is becoming deeply affected by the story being told. It sparks a possibility that maybe Saito will understand that he made a poor decision in having Motome killed, and that he should apologize to Hanshiro. On the contrary, Saito not only doesn't apologize, but he calls for an even harsher punishment on Hanshiro, thinking that he was some kind of crazy psychopath. Listening to Hanshiro's story, it made sense as to why Hanshiro was so angry, considering he may have only wanted to hear Saito admit he made a mistake. Saito is so caught up in his role as a counselor and Samurai master that he is evidently incapable of publicly expressing feelings of human emotion. This demonstrates how easily humans tend to abuse power, and how Saito cannot give in to Hanshiro's story that clearly points out Saito's mistake."Harakiri" is not just about the life of Samurai, but also the levels extremity in which they abide by the Boshido code. It's an interesting paradox how these samurai in the Iyi temple are so quick to judge the two Ronin who walk into their temple, yet as a viewer we tend to catch ourselves doing the same thing. There is a wide range of samurais in this film, some who are extremely dogmatic towards the Boshido code, and others who maneuver their way around it. Director Kobayashi cleverly points out the idea of humanism in cinema as it becomes the contrast to the Boshido code. Humanism shows how humans are what really matter most, and he demonstrates this, for example, with the character Hikokuro. This extremely dogmatic samurai has his hairpiece cut off in a battle with Hanshiro, which for samurai is worse than death itself, yet, Hikokuro still waits a few days before he commits Harakiri. Why? Well it raises the notion that pure and absolute dogma is a double standard in our society and is not possible for humanity. This film focuses on the significance of how history takes place in our world and how power is ultimately the factor that determines our fate. In "Harakiri" it was the role of Saito's power that created the entire plot and storyline for this film, and ends with a sense of ambiguity towards the significance of the samurai. This derived from witnessing the armor in the beginning with a striking and powerful presence, almost as if it were a spiritual god, and then seeing how in the end it is torn apart and put back together, as if it were something so insignificant as hanging a picture back on the wall. The metaphor of the janitors cleaning up after the battle leading to Hanshiro's death is such a large metaphor for the samurai culture and how so much can occur within their temples and how seemingly unimportant it tends to feel after the fact. Although the film has a dramatic plot, it is the critique on powerful people in society that transforms this film into a something more than your typical samurai battle movie.

Also known as "Seppuku," this surprising Japanese tale is beautiful to look at but a discomfort to sit through. In 1630 Japan, an older stranger comes to a warlord's house to commit harakiri, an honorable suicide involving self disembowelment with a sharp blade. The head of the house tells the stranger of an earlier visitor who came to do the same thing, when in actuality the visitor was hoping to be kept on at the house as a samurai. The members of the house forced the young man to kill himself anyway. The warlord's house has its own traditions: the harakiri seekers must use their own sword to kill themselves and they must choose someone who will decapitate them as the harakiri is committed. The young visitor carried a dull sword made of bamboo, and in flashback we watch his excruciating pain as he tries to do his honorable act before finally being put out of his misery. It turns out the stranger knew the young visitor slightly. They were from the same warlord's house that was broken up earlier. The stranger readies for harakiri, and names three different men to serve as his "second," the man who will remove his head at the appropriate time. What follows are many revelations as to the true relationships between the players.For a decades old film, the few instances of violence and gore here are jolting. There is much talk of honor here, and this film could serve as a parallel to Japan itself after its defeat in World War II. Should the country bow to honor and humbly accept defeat, or try to rise against its conquerors figuratively and stay proud? The black and white cinematography here is gorgeous, every frame looks like a pencil drawing. A climactic duel filmed on a windswept field is so beautiful I did not want it to end. This is the kind of film that would have suffered if shot in color. The musical score is a harsh combination of ancient instruments and dramatic percussion, resulting in spine tingling moments where only the music tells you what characters are thinking. At 134 minutes, this is dull. I mean really dull. There are just a couple of action sequences, the acting is great, but there are too many scenes of dialogue that go nowhere. Another problem: although subtitled, many of the stoic samurai warriors barely moved their lips in the scenes, resulting in confusion as to who is speaking while you read the subtitles. The story is like a good novel, but its execution is too somber and practiced. There are no light moments here, and that really adds to the tension, which comes and goes. I will recommend "Harakiri," especially to Japanese film buffs, but be prepared for a film that actually seems longer than it is.

Harakiri dives into many different themes such as perception, judgement, and loyalty. When the story of Motome is told the viewer begins pass judgement onto him and his motives. Later on we find out that his motives are essentially pure. Considering the deeper themes of the movie we see in the end a metaphor for what happens when humanism comes second to loyalty to a code. The film uses one of the most creative forms of story telling to convey a complex and deep message. The complexity of the plot adds a deep element of surprise that provokes thought. Kobayashi uses characters to represent extremes of personalities as well institutions. The film falls short many times in keeping the audiences attention, and misses out on many opportunities to capitalize on the sudden shifts in plot and tone. This consistent variable makes the film a very long winded two hours. By the end of the film you might feel as though your mind was subjected to something far more exhausting than watching a film. If you manage to power through many forced emotions from the actors and over dramatic timing than you can actually begin to appreciate the deeper themes conveyed through the story telling of the film. Kobayashi masterfully crafted scenarios in the film that made you like many of the other characters within it, because neither of you know the whole truth until you are hit with it. This film goes through great lengths humanize certain characters while limiting itself in passing judgement on others. You begin to learn that when everyone follows a certain philosophy the difference in perspective and interpretation can mean everything. Over all this film uses many different clever tactics to add depth to action and entertaining gore. Although much of the pacing of the film and cinematography leave something to be desired this is still an extremely well executed and intelligent film.

"Who can know the depths of another man's heart?" Hanshuro TsugumoApart from its sheer story-telling gravitas and technical splendour, Kobayashi's Hara-kiri is especially lauded for its plea to look closer, to examine a little more deeply the troubles of those not as fortunate as us. When I watched it for the first time, I was blown away by the arresting wallop of this tension-saturated story's narration , and it was on the second viewing years later that I registered with more delicate acuity, its eloquent entreaty for a more compassionate look at the surface issues of our brethren. Particularly in Japan, the practice of bowing to the larger system and the concept of "honour" being maintained at all costs, looms especially large but of what use is honour if it makes us lose everything dear to us? Hara-kiri takes on the form of a formidable Samurai drama and builds this visceral sentiment with inexorable power, the vise of its narrative swirling and tightening until the physical carnage at the end isn't necessary - the foes have already been annihilated with gentle words. World-class cinematography and flawlessly strong acting further power this monochrome scorcher.Pic opens with a wide-angle black-'n'-white canvas , the neatness and sparse beauty of which is the trademark of director Masaki Kobayashi. Notice how clean these compositions are, whether it is the large ground ouside a chieftan's house, the inner courtyard with its settled pebbles and carefully coiffed platforms for sitting, or even a poor man's wooden house bereft of much conveniences and yet almost spacious in its tidy gestalt. The framing is immaculate when Motome Chijiwa (Akira Ishihama) - a young Samurai struggling for survival - sits with folded knee - in a martial lord's house in front of a tough-jawed warrior who listens to his case. It is 1630 in the Edo region of Japan - peace has been declared in the land but it has devolved into internal war for the highly trained swordsmen called Samurai - they find no employment now, jobs are scarce with workers pouring into any open job-site and Motome is pushed away by a supervisor who cries out that the supervisor will be punished if authorities find out that the formal warrior class is being employed for menial jobs. Motome reports to the House of Li , as other Samurai have done before him, that this utter penury is so dishonourable that he would rather commit Seppuku by disemboweling himself with his own sword in this martial house's courtyard as a final act of honour. The House of Li, manned by fierce-looking superiors, is fed up with this pattern of supposedly suicidal Samurais - they see that many such applicants are willing to accept some money and go away without killing themseles as they initially declared to do. At this stage, Kobayashi racks up the sense of foreboding , panic and icy fear with such elan that the ensuing twenty minutes ranks as one of the most implacable turn of events in black-'n'-white cinema. A few days later, a middle-aged man named Hanshuro Tsugomo (Tatsuya Nakadai), bearded and rather emaciated-looking, shows up at the House of Li with a similar request. He is told the story of Motome Chijiwa as a warning - but Tsugumo, with a wry expression that is beyond gallows humour, calmly states that he will indubitably execute as promised. As great as the previous tightly coiled sequence was, this succeding chapter matches it with its slow burn and unbearable tension which Tsugumo stretches far past breaking point with a story he unspools. Counsellor Saito (Rentaro Mikuni) , heading the house in the absence of the martial lord, is , to put it presisely - driven nuts - by this seemingly interminable narration by the grave-faced Tsugumo but I never got tired of hearing it as the latter lays one dialogue upon another like one revelatory card against the next one till the stakes indicate not just one death but many more. Saito , his strings plucked like a hen stripped to the bone , retreats to the house unable to take more.In other jidaigeki (period-films) like Kurosawa's great "Throne of Blood", the performances though solid do not evoke my specific praise but in Harakiri ,the thespian finesse is on prime display - this could very well have been a starkly lit theater-drama. One can almost feel the cool breeze of happiness coursing through Motome's smiling immensely relieved face after the stifling humidity of despair, alas later , stomach-churning panic sets in to seize his mien. Tsugumo's nominally amused ,mostly dead-serious physiognomy never ever raises its voice but the prosody of his message undulates with the timeless meaning of great scripture. And then there's Saito , more c**t than counsellor, who's so drunk with power and delusions of tough wisdom that his sobriety is nullified by incurable hauteur.I was vastly disappointed by the fight at the end on my first viewing - having brought me to the very peak of expectation, Harakiri's climactic sword-fight seemed not even close to the supremely choreographed ahead-of-its-time bristling magnificence of Daibosatsu toge's finisher. But then as Saito himself says , Tsugumo is a "half-starved" Samurai who's already been through many hells so it is perhaps unfair to expect him to again fight like Japan's greatest champion. The denouement is a sobering indictment of the way history often operates, and the film eventually reclaims its spell-binding emotional and technical territory . To watch Hara-kiri , then , is to acknowledge that even in 1962 when so much of the rest of the world was learning the ropes of top-tier movies, Japan was already capable of engineering peerless cinema.

The film Harakiri directed by Masaki Kobayashi pulls at your emotions and your stomach. The beginning of the film can be a bit confusing if you don't pay close attention to what is going on. You are lead into a very teeth-clenching moment of watching a man (Motome) perform Harakiri with a bamboo sword in front of his peers. One of the most visually gruesome scenes I have seen in a film. While the scene is very graphic, it serves it's purpose in setting up the film for how meaningful the film is to Japanese, Samurai and just human nature in general. At the start of the film, we don't know much about this man behind the "disrespectful" bamboo sword but as the movie goes on, we learn more and more about Motome and the reason behind his flaws in following the strict Bushido Code. The film shows a Renoir-esc way of thinking; every man has his reasons for his choices and every man has a story. According to the Samurai culture, Motome was a disgrace to the name of Samurai and deserved little respect. Little did the Iyi clan know that Motome had good reason for the way he was. Kobayashi making a superb Samurai film in the early '60s is like David Vs. Goliath. Kurosawa was on top of his game at this time, and somehow Masaki Kobayashi managed to create a Samurai film on par with the quality of Kurosawa, while staying true to his own style and merit instead of copying what others did before him.The first thing that struck me was that this film, more than 50 years later, still looks fantastic. Especially the great use of high contrast lighting, something you barely see in Japanese productions, set the tone both visually and thematically. The director of photography uses a lot of symmetric shots which look beautiful but tell a story as well. For me the highlight of this film was Motome Chijiiwa's seppuku. This scene was shocking, absurd and also very unpredictable. Excellent editing and cinematography created an unforgettable, yet uncomfortable moment. The turn of events, which slowly unfold as the film progresses is unexpected and will surprise you. But most of all, it will impress you. The director uses some very (without giving too much away) notable techniques to strengthen the effect.Tatsuya Nakadai, one of the greats in Samurai cinema, has some of the most amazing body language you will ever see in movies! I noticed how much work and detail he put into this character by not focusing on his eyes, but rather on his feet - which show that he really is portraying a Samurai. My only flaw is that the beginning of the film, the first twenty minutes or so, does not set the tone which I found to be a bit confusing and off putting.This is one of the greatest films from the golden age of Japanese cinema. It holds up very well and you will walk away very satisfied. If you get the chance, go watch it!

The way Masaki Kobayashi filmed this movie was unlike anything I've ever seen. At the beginning we are introduced to a young samurai who is now a ronin, Tsugumo Hanshirō, who comes to the house of the Iyi Clan asking permission to perform Harakiri on his property. The clan becomes very angry when they discuss whether they should let him or not, knowing that many ronin have gone to many clans asking to perform harakiri, with no intentions of doing so, but instead getting sent away with some money. Believing that young Hanshirō had no intention of harakiri, and just wanted money, they granted him his wish to preform the sacred act on their land. Now you can see how distraught Tsugumo looks, and we almost feel happy. They caught him in his shameful act, now making him commit suicide seems almost justifiable instead of downright cruel. Tsugumo begs them for just a day or two, he swears he'll come back but now the samurais are set on teaching this disgraceful samurai a lesson and won't let him leave, even when they discover his swords are wooden. It's shocking, but you feel the need to side with the Iyi Clan, believing what they did is justifiable. Then, as the story goes on, we come to realize Tsugumo came there as a last resort, looking for any way to save his dying wife and dying child. He sold his swords, an ultimate form of disgrace in this culture, to help feed them and take care of them. He would do anything for them, even risk his life and his honor. Showing us that even though samurais live and die by the Bushido code, there are things that take precedence over that, like family and love. This film is a great example of that, and was directed beautifully.

Harakiri is the fourth classic-Japanese film I've seen, after Samurai 1 Musashi, Rashomon, Seven Samurai. It is comfortably my favourite as unlike the others it hasn't noticably dated nor has any clear flaws.The glacial pace doesn't drag as we're treated to a near-constant stream of visually-striking compositions, a photographer's film! The black-n-white is quite beautiful, with just the right amount of contrast (I recommend the Bluray, for optimal dynamic range).What the camera does is one thing, a good film still needs a compelling narrative, and we get that too. The first half-hour is a little confusing, but once the story finds its groove (or rather, once the viewer has 'tuned in') then it's quite gripping. We want to know what Tsugumo's game is...The most impressive accomplishment of the narrative is how it puts its main message across, regarding bushido. I won't explicitly state that message here, as first-time viewers should experience it within the film. It's an impressive ending.The cast are all decent, music totally sparse yet effective. Subtitles were fine, clear & concise. The action is mostly quite good (for an early-60's flick) tho' there was one sword-swipe which clearly missed its mark despite the victim falling prey to it. Forgiveable, given the age of the film...and understandable, given the actors used real swords! The sets and setting feel authentic, tho' lacking a little in variety. While the slow pacing and precise dialogue isn't an issue, it does make Harakiri a 'watch-when-in-the-mood' type film...not one to put on at any time.Overall a strong 8/10. The first classic-japanese to get that score. I already enjoy anime & horror from Japan-cinema (Akira, Grave of the Fireflies & The Grudge are probably my top 3 japanese films)...I wasn't sure if the 50's/60's stuff was for me. Now with Harakiri I'm beginning to see the appeal. On account of this strong showing the next film of this ilk will be from the same director: either Kwaidan or deep dive into his Human Condition trilogy.

While initially appearing to be a study of the eternal conflict between individual needs and the demands of tradition, HARAKIRI is actually a clear-eyed and savage indictment of human (particularly male) vanity.To me there are two key scenes in the film. First, the enforced ritual suicide of the young samurai early in the film. This has got to be one of the most brutal, toe-curling scenes ever put on film (although there is no gore). What is particularly striking is the juxtaposition of the twisting, writhing, screaming man against the silent, immobile, formally arranged background. This has the effect of giving the environment, or tradition/society/law, increased weight and making the individual appear weaker, transient, more mutable, and thus more subject to error. In other words Kobayashi appears to pay all due deference to the culture and belief system that have created the horror we have just witnessed. He consciously uses the the techniques of classic formalist Japanese cinema (static shots, formal spatial design, exactly replicated point of view shots, etc.) to give us a sense of the weight and power of custom bearing on the individual.The second scene comes at the end of the middle section of the film during which time we have been given a detailed examination of the relationships between the members of the small family and the increasing sense of desperation and despair that has entered the home with the deadening encroachment of poverty. When the temple officials tell the tale of the "honorable death" of the young father in this setting (they are somewhat more brightly lit - "cleaner" than their surroundings) THEY are now what appears mutable or insubstantial and their talk of fame, honor, and tradition is perceived as pompous, empty cant. In short they are shown as posturing, bullying members of some "boys club" whose membership is based on vanity and who are totally divorced from the realities of existence. These realities would include, most prominently, our duties to our family and friends, not just our personal honor (ego?). At this point in the film the young father's begging now appears an act of courage and virtue, his suicide would have been one of cowardice and vanity. The film suggests that suicide may be the easier of the choices faced by those placed in the position of this father in this culture. Death provides social approval, lasting fame, and freedom from the grind of responsibility. Continuing to be a husband and father would here only bring disgrace. This could be seen as a powerful indictment of what can occur when women are not accorded a place of respect and/or authority within a culture.This is a passionate, clear-eyed, stringently crafted film that is marred only very slightly by occasional use of that addiction of 60's filmakers: the zoom lens, and an (admittedly exciting) action ending that somewhat distracts from the film's main themes (love the toppling of that idol though). 9.5/10.

Harakiri, to me, just lacked the immersion factor to keep me hooked. I believe this is for a multitude of reasons:
Firstly, there are two stories of sorts. One of which is the Samurai telling his story before committing Harakiri. The second is how he got to that point. These two stories separately would work however they do not share the same amount of action throughout. This is the thought about rising action through movies and how that should be applied to keep the audience invested. Harakiri does not do that and therefore lacks the urgency needed.
Secondly, the second act was much weaker than the first and last as there was basically no action, which felt necessary as they foreshadowed and alluded to it but it never came, leaving a sense of an unanswered question.
Thirdly and lastly, the amount and use of exposition. Sometimes exposition can be done eloquently, but in this it is clunky and does not fit in. For example, a samurai (about to commit Harakiri) is asking about it.
There are a lot of things good with this movie however. Namely the score and cinematography. This is one of the best shot movies I've seen. Obviously it's in a grainy, black-and-white and I don't even think you can see it in in HD. But those shots and camera movements is jaw-dropping at times. And the score is, for lack of a better word, weird. Its much less music and a combinations of sounds. This truly makes for an incredible sound experience, as the combination of drums, silence and shrill notes creates incredible tension alone. This score is so good that you could sense the emotion without hearing dialogue, nor seeing visuals.
The act of Harakiri itself is definitely a not-so-subtle metaphor for masculinity, pride and mental health; predominately in men. Especially how they would rather 'bite the bullet' or, in this instance, take a painful sword to the abdomen than have to confront taking. This is doubly so as through the movie as he has responsibilities of a men, to his children and his faction.
I like it, especially the concept, but it's just a bit slow and ungripping for me.

Harakiri is a 1962 samurai film, directed by Masaki Kobayashi. It takes place in 17th century Japan, finally peaceful times for the nation after a long era of war and bloodshed. Many samurai are now masterless, "ronin", struggling to survive in a world that no longer needs their skill as warriors. Hanshiro Tsugumo, now a ronin as well, arrives at the gates of the Iyi clan with one request: a proper place to kill himself in the ritual of seppuku, as his life are too poor and devoid of honor to go on living. As his interactions with the clan proceed and his intentions are slowly examined and unraveled, we learn that there is more than meets the eye to Tsugumo's request.This movie is a slow-burn, with its first half handling the suspense surrounding Tsugumo's story in a very immersive, satisfying and masterful way. The premise of the film sounds simple at first, but it's developed slowly, each detail revealed making an impact upon the viewer, and it really got me hooked on my first time watching.The cinematography is pretty straight forward, but the harsh compositions often do well in showing the brutality of the world, the unforgiveness where we might have expected something else. The bamboo-sword scene is easily one of the best in the whole film for this exact reason, this harshness in which everything is presented. The slow, excruciating pain of the scene, made me feel like I was there. Love it.The ominous soundtrack adds a lot to the immersiveness of the film, its dark and twisted notes fitting to the era in which the movie takes place, foreboding, bare and odd. Like it a lot, as well.Tatsuya Nakadai is especially great as Tsugumo, communicating the grit he has along with his special kind of cynicism, and his softer side as well. Range is shown here, definitely. The other actors were solid as well, though nothing as impactful or memorable acting-wise, in my opinion.After the halfway point of the film I feel like it has some heavy exposition, that made this part of the film a little more tiresome to watch. It's important and I don't know if there was a way to communicate this part of the story better (and right from the topknot moment and until the end of the movie, things get exciting again), but it was less smooth than the first half, for sure.I'd also like to say that this film is not very rewatchable, to me at least- its slowness is fine when you don't know the details of the story, but on rewatch the movie is a little tougher to digest, since you already know everything that should keep you in suspense, there isn't that much to unpack, and things overall move me less. I was quite tired when rewatching the movie, so maybe that had a bit of an impact, but I still think that what I've said is relevant.In conclusion, Harakiri is a pretty solid film. Its first half is full of suspense, a well-crafted slow-burn that lets us into the harsh and brutal world of the samurai, and even though there's a little tiresome (but essential) part in the middle of the film it also ends in a strong note. Not very rewatchable, but definitely worth watching. I'm feeling an 8.1/10 on this one.

Robbie Lynch"Hara-kiri" is a great film that challenges the strict adherence to traditions and rituals. The story took many unpredictable twists and turns. This, combined with the great use of the camera, made for an unforgettable movie. The movie began with a former samurai named Hanshiro Tsugumo who asked permission to commit Hara-kiri (traditional samurai suicide) at the House of Iyi.  The members of the House let Hanshiro in and tried to scare him off by telling him of a former samurai who had tried to do the same feat.  That samurai was named Motome Chijiiwa.  He had come to the House threatening Hara-kiri, but he had really wanted money.  The elders, however, accepted his request as truth and granted him permission to commit Hara-kiri. Motome was obviously surprised at this response and asked for a day or two to take care of his affairs and then to return.  This request was refused and the Hara-kiri ritual commenced.  However, the ritual had not run smoothly. Motome's sword was not made of steel but of bamboo. Despite this disgrace, Motome was still forced to commit Hara-kiri.  Motome killed himself with great difficulty and while so doing further disgraced himself by having bitten off his tongue. Hanshiro Tsugumo was not moved by this story and still threatened to commit Hara-kiri.  The elders once again accepted the request and the ritual began. Before the ritual began, however, Hanshiro asked for the right to pick his second (the one who would cut off his head after Hanshiro disemboweled himself with his sword).  The request was granted.  However, the three men Hanshiro selected as his second were not well that day.  While messengers were sent to one of the three men, Hanshiro told his story. Hanshiro told of how eleven years earlier his friend was dying and asked Hanshiro to look after his son.  Hanshiro accepted the request and responded to his friend that he would protect the son with his life, while raising his own daughter as a single parent.  The son was actually Motome.  Hanshiro went on to explain how Motome and his daughter, Miho, become married.  The couple then bore a son named Kingo.  Since Motome was a former samurai, he could not find any work so he was forced to sell his sword blades (which are part of his soul) in order to support his family.  One day Kingo grew terribly ill and needed a doctor, but the family had no money.  So Motome went to the House of Iyi in hopes of stealing some money but he never returned.  Later Motome's body was returned to Miho.  Two days later Kingo died and within three days after that, Miho died.  Hanshiro went on to tell how he secured revenge by cutting of the top hair knots of the three best swordsmen in the House of Iye (acts which were worse than death), the same three men whom he had just requested to act as the second in the Hara-kiri ritual.  (Those three men later killed themselves.) Hanshiro then made the case that the rituals are ridiculous.  He only wished that he had sold his sword in order to pay for a doctor to help his grandson, Kingo.  The Lord of the House was not sympathetic to Hanshiro's story and the men in the House attacked Hanshiro.  Because he was such a great warrior, Hanshiro killed four men and wounded eight others.  While he was killing himself, he was shamefully shot.  The Lord of the House rewrote history and said that Motome, Hanshiro, and the four men that had been killed by Hanshiro had all committed Hara-kiri.  The Lord further reported that the three who had killed themselves because Hanshiro had cut their knot of hair had died of illness. "Hara-kiri" showed that rituals are sometimes unjust and, in order to live, they must at times be broken.  "Hara-kiri" was an amazing movie with simple graphics, little action, but with a powerful story line.

Seppuku, a film directed by Masaki Kobayashi, is simply a movie masterpiece with amazing cinematography. It  displays a stunning story of revenge. The film is shot in a style where almost every scene is framed with the many rectangular and square shapes of the Japanese houses. This "framing" mirrors the way the story is told. It is a story set within a story, set within a story. The film opens with a clan retainer writing the events of a day in a book. We then look at the actual day and what it contained. The inner story is of a samurai Hanshiro Tsugumo, an ex-warrior who is without a job in a time of peace. Hanshiro approaches the clan house of Iyi seeking a holy place to preform Hara kiri. Hara kiri, also known as Seppuku, is an honourable way for a samurai to commit suicide. The samurai uses his own sword to disembowel himself before a second, a swordsman behind him, decapitates the samurai. Hanshiro's request was a very common event in those times. Many times a clan, instead of granting the samurai their wish for a holy site,  would instead provide the exwarrior with food, clothes, or money. Sometimes they would even bring the masterless warrior into their own clan. Upon hearing Hanshiro's request, a clan official tells  him  a story of the samurai Motome Chijiiwa.  Chijiiwa also approached the house of Iyi a month earlier. Chijiiwa  requested a place to preform Hara Kiri. Chijiiwa though, was only though seeking money. Chijiiwa meets a terrible fate because the Honourable clan elders decide they do not want their clan to be known as one which offers food, money or clothes to just any samurai requesting seppuku. This they felt, would bring floods of samurai to their house. The clan forces Chijiiwa to preform Hara kiri but upon inspecting his blades, they find that they are merely blades of bamboo. It is said that "a samurai's sword is his soul." Chijiiwa is forced to die by the sword of bamboo. Hanshiro, after hearing this story, is asked again, if he really wishes to request their holy place to preform Hara kiri. His reply: yes. This is merely the opening to an astonishing story. The movie Seppuku is a beautifully crafted masterpiece of revenge and honour amo
Just watch it; it will have an impact in who you are. Easily one of the best films of all time.

(Don't read this if you haven't seen the movie)Dear Dr. McMahon,Masaki Kobayashi's Hara Kiri presents the viewer with several interesting criticisms of Japanese society which have relevance in western society as well. The movie is a commentary on the social elite and on the way the truth is presented as opposed to the actual truth.Even from the onset of the movie Kobayashi is poking at the social elite. He starts with the image of smoke blowing around a hollow statue of a member of the samurai class. He develops this idea throughout the movie and blatantly beats the viewer over the head with it with the way he portrays the head of the house of Iyi. With the abolishment of many feudal houses brings an excess of samurai. These ronin roam the country in poverty because their honour code does not allow them to work. Motome at one point in the movie tries to get a job but is unable to because of his status. The honour code is a set of superficial rules which have little to do with actual honour. It's more about how a person dresses and wears their hair than any achievement moral or physical. Surprisingly one of the only things these samurai can do for food or money is threaten to commit seppuku. The honour code does not allow honest work but it does allow threatening people in an attempt to extort money out of them. Motome sells the blades of his swords to try to save his dying wife and son. The self-righteous head of the house of Iyi lives in luxury while the truly righteous Hanshiro and Motome live in poverty on the verge of starvation.The head of the house of Iyi is made to be loathed in all of his self-righteousness. Dear Dr. McMahon, In the film Seppuku, a fluid portrayal of the morals upheld by Japanese society is only the surface of the black and white masterpiece. Through this medium the director is incredibly successful at insinuating and attacking many social issues that plagued the world in the 60's, when the film was made, and continue to act as a disease which is slowly gnawing away at the society which we all live in today. Its ironic that stories that are set centuries before the time in which they are presented, are more than often more relevant to present issues than many of the attempts made in what is considered the "modern style". No movie proves this point more true than Masaki Kobayashi's Seppuku, with camera work that is eerily reminiscent of still photography, each scene unique and harrowing in the feeling of tranquillity that penetrates the very skin of the viewer. This is the backbone to the film that provides both emotions and acts as a stage for the powerful events, that from the very beginning prove ominous and awaiting disaster. The happenings that ensue are laden with a quality that seems to be perfected by the director, the subtle art that is symbolism. It would be hard to find a movie that uses more techniques for exhibiting symbolism, this alone makes Seppuku a rare work. Seemingly around every corner lies another allusion or example of the corruption that surrounds the central scene of the movie, The House of Iyi. It would be an injustice to be cursory in examining the various symbols that are in the movie, rather each one deserves a complete and thorough dissection respectively. The hero of the story, Hanshiro, has exposed the corruption of the House of Iyi which stolidly made the statement that it is a honorable place. Through the movie we find out of the hard times which fall upon the daughter, son-in-law and grand-daughter of Hanshiro. We are made aware that the journey that Hanshiro makes to the house is not that of discovery and closure(by his request to commit Hara-Kiri), but rather of an objective of vengeance that is both silent and furious, portrayed perfectly by Tatsuya Nakadai. When Hanshiro is blamed by the head of Iyi that he has attempted to bring shame and dishonor to the house, the hero makes it clear that the place never had any to begin with. The House being the symbol of authority and the protagonist being the symbol of insurrection to an unjust system, the fate of the man is predictable, as is true in "real life". The order of the killing of Hanshiro is imminent, and is taken head on by the willing hero. During the time where Hanshiro explains of his motivations for the request of Hara-Kiri at this particular house, he sits attentively on a plain white mat. As the story proceeds and the order of death is made, Hanshiro remains on the mat, being attacked at all sides.  Pride and lunacy is a dangerous combination when fighting, and when attacked, this mixture proves to be fatal for the House of Iyi. Many lives are lost while trying to slay this one man and the first deaths occur on the mat where Hanshiro began the tale. The previously white mat is now stained with a black streak that seeps deep into the cloth. After many more casualties on the part of the House, Hanshiro finally finishes what he came to the house to do, commits ritual Hara-Kiri, leaving the House in chaos. A proud establishment will try with all of its might to remain in the image of what it thinks it is, covering up whatever is necessary to uphold the guise of its ideals. While the blood of this event marks numerous places where embarrassment occurred, it is for the most part cleaned up, leaving no sign of any sort of threat to normalcy. All that is, save the sheet where Hanshiro was sitting.  While cleaning up after the disaster, minions of Iyi take off the cloth that covers the board that Hanshiro was formerly kneeling on. The board is the justification that is held by the hero, attached firmly to the ground, and when the sheet is removed the viewer realizes that the beliefs that were held by Hanshiro were no mere front, but rather a true and enduring persistence for what he believed in. Of course nothing would be more fitting than a lasting example of the righteous rebel and the establishment which he fought against. While the stain on the sheet is taken to be washed, the camera remains fixed on the board, an identical mark of blood remains. No matter how much it may think it has stayed the same, the house has been effected by this occurrence. The possible references that can be made by this symbolism are both untold and unspecified. Analogies are applicable no matter what you are trying to compare, whether it be a ruling government, a specific person, or perhaps just a stab at authority and its corruption in general. Power enables ability to for the most part, erase, or cover up anything that could appear contrary to the ideas that are expressed by the one in power. The film Hara-Kiri though gives an uplifting reminder to all oppressed and a biting example to the oppressors; that even though a wrong can be covered up and washed, the stain will remain.

DO NOT READ IF U DIDN'T SEE THE MOVIEThe compelling tale of Seppuku, Masaki Kobayashi's visual masterpiece, takes place during the feudal era in seventeenth century Japan.  This film, as well as several other films directed by Kobayashi, was inspired by his own individual wartime experience.  Each of Kobayashi's works reverberate his passionate disdain of societal authority and political corruption. Kobayashi was an analytical mastermind because of his extraordinary ability to dispute the abuse of power clearly and sensibly.  Seppuku is the enigmatic story of how absolute power blinds those who possess it from seeing or believing a virtuous reality. The protagonist of the story is Hanshiro Tsugumo, an aged and unemployed samurai.  He had lost everything that had any value to him, so he journeyed to the House of Iyi, the mansion inhabited by a respected samurai clan, to perform harakiri, the Japanese ritual where a samurai living in shame commits suicide by  means of eviscerating oneself.  This is the most honorable type of death for this situation. Tsugumo arrived at the House of Iyi prepared to die.  The clan elder of the House of Iyi questioned Tsugumo's `true' motive because of  previous impoverished unemployed samurai who threatened to perform harakiri only to extort money from the wealthy clan.  The clan elder then told Tsugumo of a specific instance where this `dishonorable' behavior occurred. The clan elder told Tsugumo about the story of Motome Chijiiwa, in an attempt to uncover his `true' motive.  Chijiiwa, like Tsugumo, was a member of the disbanded Shogunate clan.  When the clan elder asked, `Did you know Chijiiwa?' Tsugumo gave no immediate answer.  The clan elder continued with his story and said that the clan forced Chijiiwa to perform harakiri even when he asked to be given a boon.  The most sickening aspect of Chijiiwa's death was that he had to perform harakiri with a sword made from bamboo, which meant his soul was worthless in the samurai culture because one's sword is one's soul. After the story Tsugumo was asked if he still wanted to perform harakiri. The unshaken Tsugumo did not waver in his decision to perform harakiri, but he first had to choose a second, a samurai that assists one in harakiri by cutting off one's head when their entrails are completely exposed . Coincidentally, out of three seconds, none were present that day at the House of Iyi.  Tsugumo requested that one of the three men that he had requested be summoned to accompany him for his performance of harakiri. While a group of clan members were summoning the three absent samurais, Tsugumo told the members of the House of Iyi the tragic incidents in his life that led him to want to perform harakiri. In this story Tsugumo revealed that he did know Motome Chijiiwa, he took care of him when Chijiiwa's father died.  Tsugumo treated him like a son. Years later, Tsugumo asked Chijiiwa to marry his precious daughter Miho. Chijiiwa reluctantly said yes to his mentor's proposal due to his financial state.  After Miho and Chijiiwa were married, they had a child.  Shortly after the child was born, Miho and the baby became extremely ill.  The family did not have enough money for a doctor, so they could not receive treatment.  Chijiiwa tried various ways of obtaining money, but  none worked.  Chijiiwa then traded in his precious sword for money to treat his wife and his son.  When Chijiiwa returned home, he told Tsugumo and Miho that he was going to journey to a moneylender in another city, and that he would return soon.  When he did not return, Tsugumo thought that Chijiiwa had left the burden of his ill daughter and grandson upon him. When three men from the House of Iyi came to Tsugumo's home with the body of Chijiiwa, the men indicated that Chijiiwa's life was meaningless due to his death by a sword of bamboo.  Shortly after this visit, Miho and her son died of sickness.  Tsugumo hunted down the men that visited him, and he cut off each of their ponytails.  He showed the ponytails to the clan elder to show that the honor of the House of Iyi meant nothing.  Disgusted by this display, the clan elder sent all of his men to attack Tsugumo.  He fought off many opponents, and destroyed many precious artifacts in the House of Iyi.  When he was about to perform harakiri, he was shot.  This action vividly portrayed that the House of Iyi, and possibly other houses, was corrupt and had no honor.  The disturbing ending showed all of the blood being cleaned up, and the false idols being restored and replaced.  The House of Iyi remained for many years after that isolated event.

The film Harakiri, directed by Masaki Kobayashi, is a tale of honor. However, involves a conflict of honor, between doing what is morally right and doing what is expected of you.  A person is unable to choose both of these in some circumstances, such as the ones brought forth in Harakiri.The tale of Harakiri begins on May 16, 1630 with a man named Hanshiro Tsugumo arriving at the gates of the House of Iyi, requesting a corner of the manor to commit hara-kiri, which is a form of suicide ritualized by the samurai.  After being asked if he knew another retainer of the Gishi House named Motome Chijiiwa, he responds that there were thousands of retainers and is the tale of a former samurai who arrived at their door.The story tells of him arriving at the House of Iyi, requesting a place to commit hara-kiri.  They, instead, tell him to bathe and change clothes, as he will be meeting with the head of household.  However, after changing and being cleaned up, he is instead told to change once more into the clothes of the hara-kiri ritual.  Even after finding out his blades are made of bamboo and his multiple requests for a few days' delay, they force him to commit the ritual with his flimsy blades.Hanshiro still makes the request to commit hara-kiri and they give him permission to do so.  Then, when it comes time to name his second, he names three people, all of which had claimed they were indisposed that day.  To take up some of the time, Hanshiro decides he will tell them his life story. Within his first few words, he has said that Motome is a lad of some acquaintance, which is a great understatement.Hanshiro worked for the House of Gishi until it's downfall, and then proceeded to do various jobs to keep food on the table for himself and his daughter, Miho.  After being propositioned by wealthy men to take his daughter as a concubine, he requests that Motome and Miho wed.  They do so and have a child named Kingo.The family does what they can for a while, until Miho comes down with the `red death', or tuberculosis.  She is confined and is unable to go anywhere. Little to her knowledge, she transfers the deadly disease onto young Kingo, who takes ill.  Motome rushes about to find work to earn money to take care of his wife and son, but finds nothing, as samurai are not allowed to have the normal jobs of citizens.Desperation takes over and Motome sells his blades for money to take care of Miho and Kingo, who are growing worse by the day.  Motome hears about samurai threatening hara-kiri at the doorsteps of other Houses and being offered jobs or pittance, so he leaves, as it is known, for the House of Iyi.  He returns much later, dead, brought back by some of the retainers of Iyi.Hanshiro then explains how he got revenge for Motome, and Miho and Kingo indirectly, by cutting the top knots off of the three most involved retainers of Iyi.  The three most involved with the hara-kiri of Motome Chijiiwa.  Then, a fierce battle rages between Hanshiro and the Iyi retainers.  Hanshiro Tsugumo is eventually struck down, but not without causing wounds to multiple samurai who were forced into battle.  The House of Iyi covers up the days events, hiding all of the destruction caused by the arrival of Hanshiro.

Just like the sharp edges of shadows on a cloudless summer day, Harakiri is a beautiful play of surprising contrasts that will unravel, slowly, towards a realistic depiction of the frail human condition, while emphasizing the complete lack of honor in an apparently honorable society. The relaxing atmosphere created from early in the film, defined by the calm weather, smooth camera movements, and pleasant static shots will soon be overshadowed by inner tensions and profound feelings, creating a well-defined contrast that won't dissipate for almost the entire duration of the plot.Harakiri dives into the implications of sudden political landscape change. A change that profoundly affects its characters and more specifically the Samurai class. After endless conflicts, a widespread peace has established in the country. The Edo period has begun some 30 years ago and many samurais had become masterless. Without a master to serve they become Ronins, wanderers, struggling to persevere in a world they are not prepared for. While adapting to a new lifestyle, their moral code is slowly being exposed, shown for what it truly is.Self-deceiving and ignorant, the few samurais that still have a master, walk on a rigid and intricate political maze, distorting everlasting truths and morals for self-benefit and for appearances. Living in an age without any conflict or war, they struggle to sustain their image through questionable ethics, ignoring obvious truths or even worse, being completely blind to them.Trying to be true to himself, the main character is forced by the surroundings to progress, mature and eventually accept reality. He descends, resolute and decisive to bring forth an incredible catharsis by revealing with crystal clarity that the "Thing, we all call samurai honor is ultimately a facade", bringing ultimate judgement and showing how idealistic and relative honor can be.The word "Honor" is used 17 times within this movie, but not even once did it represent its true meaning.Everything unfolds supported by gorgeous aesthetic visuals fusing with an exceptionally well told story, complex characters and music that amplifies the tension to perfection. Japanese architecture never lacked in beauty, surprising with its minimalism, straight sharp lines and symmetry. Being well aware of this, Masaki Kobayashi made sure that every shot was perfectly composed and every element used to its full extent.Harakiri tells a story whose motifs have a deeply instilled permanence that will never become redundant as long as politics and pride continue to exist. It also recalls the frail human condition but it does it so well and with such sheer intensity and realism that it feels just like life itself in the end.

This film left me thinking on the irrationality of many that have power. Saito 's irrational rigidity speaks not so much about his control over the situation and the profound trust and loyalty he has on the symbols of his daimyos and of the bushido code, but on the fear of it disappearing. It is only when we fear for that disappearance and for the uncertainty of the future to come that we cling as much to the past and to the promises we made on the past, even when this may lead us to the extreme of irrationality and even inhumanity. Harakiri illustrates what most go through when faced to confront their beliefs and to question the legitimacy of what we swear is the ideal or best way of living/thinking/behaving; a lesson that can be applied in any situation especially if it involves a decision that, as in the film, will affect a third person directly. I want to make mine the words of another reviewer:"There are good, very good, and even great movies. But among them there are just a few that go beyond great. They belong to the league of their own. Masaki Kobayashi's "Harakiri" aka "Seppuku" is one of them. The film of rare power and humanism, of highest artistic achievements, profoundly moving, tragic like the best Shakespeare's plays, universal and timeless even if it takes place in the faraway country of 1630 [...] A Masterpiece, one of the best movies ever made, "Harakiri" deserves all its praise" I think that Harakiri is one of the greatest pieces of drama ever written (the reference to Shakespeare is very appropriate). The drama unfolds slowly but with incredible force and ever-increasing tension. But besides involving us in the tragic fate of the characters, Kobayashi denounces the hypocrisy and corruption behind the so often idealized "honor" of the Samurai. And in doing so, he also reflects on modern-day Japan's society, where appearance is what matters, and cover-up is the solution to all the problems. In a similar vein, see also "Rebellion" aka "Samurai Rebellion" (1967), another great movie by Kobayashi.As a frequent reader of IMDb, I see lots of good movies rated with 10 stars. I would reserve that rating to just a handful of movies that are above even the great movies. Harakiri is one of them.

Similarities between Kobayashi's Harakiri and films of the French new wave arose to me under the comical disobedience of authority. The combat scenes seem authentic in a way that is almost comical--ignoring what they may look like ideally, the director is able to make us feel the adrenalin present within Hanshiro during the fight scenes. This comical use of real actions, along with the demystification of the Iyi clan leader, helps expose the viewer to the idealized values present during the Tokugawa era, which although questionable, have been believed by many.

In "Harakiri," director Kobayashi creates a compelling, beautifully shot jidaigeki that has proved to have timeless thematic relevance, even in the context of our modern American culture. The film chronicles Hanshiro, an unemployed ronin with no options left, as he approaches the Iyi Clan in hopes to, if nothing else, exact vengeance for his deceased family members and point out the cruel hypocrisy of the Bushido Code.As evidenced many times throughout the course of this masterful film, strict adherence to the Bushido Code is, ironically, dishonorable. Clearly, even Kobayashi realizes that the code itself is not inherently bad; however, the problem with such strict adherence to any set of rules is that it diminishes reason, logic, and, most importantly, basic humanity. Kobayashi demonstrates the ridiculousness of the Code by having Hanshiro turn out to be the character that most truly and honestly exemplifies the Code- he comes to the Iyi Clan on behalf of his family and, at the end, stays true to his word and commits seppuku. All in all, "Harakiri" is an artful, deeply meaningful film with much to say- truly a piece of cinematic history. I find it to be particularly relevant today, given modern socioeconomic issues like unemployment, both at home and abroad. Unfortunately, many individuals are left in a state of self-induced shame. However, Kobayashi's film urges individuals to consider the less-than-honorable outside forces that may have contributed to their plight. This film is important because it emphasizes that, even well intended governments, institutions, and other authorities become so wrapped up in themselves that they deny humanity, just as they did in the plot of "Harakiri."

Japan embraces strict cultural patterns and rules and for a samurai, their is a fine line between compliability and morality when forced to follow the Bushido code. This film questions the rationality of following dogmatic practices when it results to unethical behavior. As the movie opens up with a narration from a book and closes in the same way, Kobayashi also questions the validity of history and the subjectivity of the truth. All in all, this film stands out amongst other samurai movies as it criticizes the core foundation of a culture rooted in rules and rivalry.

Jonathan Sessums `Samurai code exposed' Set in 17th-century Japan, director Masakaki Kobayahi's Harakiri (1963) stars Tatsuya Nakadai, as masterless samurai Hanshiro Tsugumo. Kobayashi's gives a horrifying display of assault on the samurai code. Nakadai plays a proud samurai fallen on hard times when his house is disbanded who displays almost superhuman effection when he is faced with defeat. A man filled with guilt, Tsugumo seeks to avenge the wrongful death of his son-in-law, Motome Chijiwa (Akira Ishihama). He marries his daughter off to this ronin, but they slip deeper and deeper into poverty, and eventually his son-in-law is forced to sell his swords and willing to attempt an act of desperation. Moteme Chijiwa asks to commit ritual suicide at the house of iyi, the estate of a powerful lord, in the hopes that he'll be given a small payoff to avoid the ritual suicide. Unfortunately the honor obsessed lord forces the desperate samurai to commit seppuku with his bamboo sword. Hanshiro Tsugumo comes to the estate asking to be allowed to commit seppuku and slowly relates his pathetic story. Here, Kobayashi ridicules the samurai system as absurd and inhuman. He falls back on false notions of "honor" and pride that sound good, but ultimately fall short when practiced in reality.Hanshiro requests that the clan's three best swordsmen act as his seconds for his act of seppuku, but they are nowhere to be found. He then reveals himself as the father-in-law of the tragic Motome and begins to exact his revenge. Arguably Kobayashi's masterpiece, this savage attack on the hypocrisy, cowardice, cruelty, and ultimate emptiness of the institution of the samurai warrior. It would certainly be enjoyed by fans of the samurai genre who prefer style, violence, a thoughtful story, and people who are interested in Japanese cinema.

The bad guys are not acting out of evil, but just working through their interpretation of honor. The good guys are not so perfect, they lie, cheat and set traps. The plot is almost Western in it's structure, a very easy film to follow, but a film that makes you feel educated and cultured. I was completely floored by the opening scene of "Hara-Kiri." It is still perhaps one of the three or four most influential pieces of cinema I have experienced. Remaining shocking for me, to this day. The fight in the windswept fields of grass is spectacular. Watch Samurai Rebellion, Kwaiden, and the Human Condition Series. Why Kobayashi isn't more written about I don't know. When I first saw this film I wrote a letter to the director, c/o the Japanese Directors Guild, it was returned months later, saying I had missed his passing away by three months. I highly recommend this picture.

The narrator of the story is the Bushido code and it is a negative critique of when you follow anything without questioning it, you are being dogmatic. When the ronin (unemployed samurai) Hanshiro goes to the Iyi clan to ask to commit Harakiri he knows he is not going to leave the sacred space alive but he went there anyway to make Saito recognize that what he had done with Motome (Hanshiro's son-in-law) was a total lack of compassion. We can see in some specifics shots that Saito is affected by what Hanshiro is saying but he can not surrender to it or otherwise it would be catastrophic. Hanshiro is actually the only one who embodies the code because he questions it and he has a broader view of it.Interesting Trivia about the movie: the battle at the end is fought with real weapons.

People that are not afraid to stand up for their sake and other people. Without them, we will never change and never prove our thoughts right.

Harakiri is a masterfully constructed period drama by director Masaki Kobayashi. The film is expertly set up and provides the viewer with a thought provoking, entertaining two hours of both brilliant dialogue and suspenseful action. The film starts with the protagonist of the story, Tsugumo Hanshiro (Tatsuya Nakadai), as an out of work Samurai requesting to commit Harakiri (Seppuku) because he feels he wants to end his life honorably instead of poor and hungry. The counselor of the clan tells Hanshiro a story similar to what is happening now and the other samurai's grisly fate to deter him, but Hanshiro remains committed to his cause. The film is told through a series of stories, using flashbacks and narration to move the story along. Kobayashi effectively used the flashbacks and allows the viewer to easily follow the story line while jumping between different stories and timelines. While the acting of Hanshiro and the Counselor is of a higher tier than most, some of the supporting actors fall flat and leave much to be desired. For example, in the film, when Hanshiro is telling a story of his daughter and her husband, the characters end up being a little flat and not living up to their full potential. Their acting wasn't pivotal in the advancement of the story so it didn't deter the viewer's enjoyment of the film.Overall this film was deep and the viewer realized that both the protagonist and antagonist both have their own motivations. I found myself thinking about this film and the messages it conveyed long after I finished watching it. There are parallels that can be drawn with current events and even could cause you to reassess your own moral code. I highly recommend this well-written film.

Kobayashi's "Harrakiri" easily enthralls the viewer through the tale of a ronin named Hanshiro who enters the house of Iyi to commit harrakiri- This is a story full of plot-twists and "aha" moments that will leave you in awe. In the beginning, we are shown the symbol of the Iyi clan- an empty suit of armor that embodies power and integrity; the essence of grandeur. It is Hanshiro's storytelling throughout the film that shows how counselor Saito of the Iyi Clan is completely dehumanized beyond reason. Counselor Saito refuses to have the clan exploited for money or clothes so he tells the tale of a ronin named Motome and his attempt to commit harrakiri with a bamboo sword. Hanshiro tells his side of the story: The heart-breaking story of Motome who did not have enough money to help his dying wife Miho and son Kingo. Counselor Saito knew he took it too far but he refused to acknowledge that he did anything wrong; he was simply following the code(the code is greater than life itself). Acknowledgement of such a thing could cause complete chaos and would make others question the validity of the bushido code and the Iyi Clan. Finally, once chaos had erupted in the house of Iyi, we are again shown the symbol of the Iyi Clan- an empty suit of armor exposed to be completely hollow and void of all honor it once held.

Tradition vs. Humanism: the revaluation of dogmas and inevitability of progress Having participated in kendo, the art of Japanese swordsmanship, for a good decade, I am somewhat familiar with the importance of tradition and discipline within the samurai culture. Of course, the tradition has lessened in it's severity overtime, but we still respect and remember it's importance and time and place in the culture. Watching the movie "Harakiri" I couldn't help but question the dogmatism of the men of the Iyi clan. In the beginning of the movie I felt slightly delightful that Motome was being teased and tortured. I judged him without even thinking about his situation. Later, finding out more details of his personal life, I felt sorry and guilty for feeling almost enjoyment for his forced suicide. Passing judgment on Motome without even knowing or trying to know what he went through shows the audience that, we as a people, it is in our nature to take the point of view of those who are telling the story. This also makes a statement on how the history we know might not be true. It could be biased by the people who wrote it. This is proved at the end where Counselor Saito rewrites the history and covers up the incidents that occurred within the Iyi house. Professor and Director Salvador Carrasco states that, "Meta history is what we get. We were privy to what happened even though Saito fabricates the history at the end." Knowing that, how can we judge or even believe the facts of history that we know now?The discipline of the followers of the Bushido code shows how sometimes, exceptions of the code should be made for the greater good. Take Motome for example: he was a respected samurai but had to resort to selling his pride as one to save his family. If the Iyi clan had the decency, the humanism to respect Motome's request or even ask him why, things might have been different. But because of their headstrong attitude and pride to follow the code, Motome and his family are inevitably doomed. Through their dogmatic attitude and self-righteousness, they lacked humanism. It is in our human nature to become greedy, pompous, and abusive when we have power. When the three retainers of the Iyi clan call in sick for having had their top buns cut off, it shows that when power is taken away, so is their self-righteousness and pride.Also, In the beginning of the film, a contrasted shogun armor is shown. It represented power and something bigger but towards the end, it represented something else. Seeing the corruption and abuse of power, the fabrication of history, I can't help but see a meaningless, empty shell of a tradition that used to mean so much more. Overall, the human condition is constantly being questioned throughout the film. With it's print-like composition and symmetrical settings clean shots and simplicity,, the solemnity and seriousness of the film is exemplified.

The movie Harakiri and the story Beyond the Pale of Vengeance both examine justice, revenge, hypocrisy, integrity and the samurai code in the Japanese, samurai culture. This enrages Hanshiro and sets out so that justice will be served to the people had played a role in this cruel act that clearly had crossed the line. Hanshiro goes out to seek revenge on the members responsible for treating Motome as they did.  Hanshiro finds the three men most responsible and cuts off each one of their top-knots instead of killing them which in the Japanese culture having your top-knot is worse then being killed because it is an act of such dishonor.  Honor is the most coveted above anything else to these members of the House of Iyi so Hanshiro's act was the most extreme act of revenge that he could have done.  Hanshiro clearly got his revenge but if he crossed the line of justice and went to far is clearly is an opinion of the reader but I believe Hanshiro's revenge was completely justifiable.The House of Iyi showed the only definite act of hypocrisy. The way they disrespected Motome showed absolutely no honor at all and was proof that their `honor code' was very superficial. Motome needed to take care of his wife and child. I had never seen a Japanese film before I saw Harakiri. At first, I thought that this film would be a typical period piece just set in Japan but that was an ignorant assumption that I made. The film follows the story of two ronins (samurai), Motome and Hanshiro, during the Tokugawa era. They each, at separate times, ask to commit harakiri (suicide) at the Iyi clan house with similar background stories. Half way through the film, the story comes around that these two ronins are related. The film's plot not only symbolizes the end of the samurai way of life, but also presents a greater meaning of humanism vs dogmatism and the corruptive nature of power. The film makes us, the audience, aware of our own humanistic, dogmatic and corrupt traits by following Hanshiro's explanation to who he is and who Motome was. Although at first, we see Motome come to the Iyi clan to commit harakiri, we also see that he does everything in his power to save his family and what his intentions were originally, making him the most honorable of samurai. The Iyi clan persecute him due to regime than considering the reasoning for his suicide. The clan represents the dogmatic samurai that think with their heads rather than their hearts. This shows the corruptive nature of power and stagnation. The film brings to attention our own ignorant assumptions that make us draw parallels between our moral code and that of the samurai code. Stylistically it is beautifully composed with balance and precision. The plot is perfectly complex yet easily understood, reflecting Japanese tradition, as not to obscure the meaning. Every scene has a deep significance and every element has a symbolic value that truly makes this film one of the best I have ever seen.

Harakiri is a film with strong denunciations of the hypocrisy of bushido (the code of the samurai).  Harakiri is a film about a family struggling to survive during a time following the battle of Sekigahara, which broke the power of the warlords.  Daimyoâ?Ts were reduced to mere vassals.  Laying strict rules and orders.  For victors the new order was peaceful and prosperous.  For the losers it was grim and hopeless.  After clans were destroyed thousands of retainers became ronin (masterless samurai). Such was the case for this family.  It all really unfolds after Motome; an unemployed samurai is forced to commit harakiri before a feudal lord. As it turned out, Motome did not even have real swords, having pawned his real ones to help provide for his family and only had bamboo replicas. Making the conclusion that he must be a con, the clan forced him to kill himself in the most painful and horrid manner with his short bamboo sword and was not beheaded until he had disemboweled his whole stomach. Hanshiro returns seemingly to perform the same suicide ritual.  In an effort to discourage him from this duty he was about to perform he is told the story of Motome. Hanshiro listens to this story with a straight face, because as it turns out, Hanshiroâ?Ts daughter Miho had been married to Motome.  Who is unable to provide for his family and find employment. The family struggles Miho and her son become extremely sick.  Fed up Motome leaves with what he believes to be a solution to his problems muttering something about borrowing money and leaves promising to return.  In a last furious display of power, Hanshiro battles against not only the countless samurai but also the hypocrisy of the bushido. Beyond the Pale of Vengeance is a gripping novel of a Buddhist monk who undertakes a seemingly impossible task of digging a 400-yard underground tunnel to fulfill his spiritual purpose to help those travelers he had previously harmed.  It shows how, in the process of conversion, he also transforms the lives of others.  It shows how no matter what a person has done, including murder and robbery, you can turn your life around and can then commit yourself to selfless service because it is your nature to do so as was demonstrated in this novel. Harakiri and Beyond the Pale of Vengeance are stories that portray great deeds done by great men.  Justice and revenge are examined in Harakiri in the plight of Motome and Hanshiro.  Motome had gone down to the House of Iyi to commit harakiri hoping instead that he would be offered a pittance and sent home in order to support his family.  Unfortunately such wasnâ?Tt the case and he was forced to commit suicide.  However, Hanshiro out of revenge went to avenge the death of his murdered son-in-law performing a courageous last stand. Beyond the Pale of Vengeance shows honor, integrity, justice, and revenge. Ryokai followed the bushido towards the end by regaining his honor and integrity by building the tunnel that would save thousands of lives, the lives he once took through a life of crime.  It also is a tale of revenge and justice because although he had recommitted his life to do the right thing his past came back to haunt him.  Jitsunosuke, the son of his slain master, Saburobei, had been looking for over ten years to avenge the death of his father that Ryokai had once killed. These two stories are great depictions of great samurai.  They both show justice, revenge, and integrity respectively but get there and show it in two different ways that show all these points perfectly.

Do not Hurry up to judgeAfter the civil wars in Japan a lot of samurais lost their jobs and became ronins. For example, at first I didn't sympathize Motome. "Harakiri" is a revolutionary Kobayashi masterpiece set in the early days of the Tokugawa Era, when Japan experienced a time of relative peace and Samurai and Ronin alike felt a new wave of challenges that start off the battlefield. The story follows a particular Ronin (or "Unemployed Samurai"), named "Motome", as he requests to commit Harakiri or "Seppuku", a Japanese form ritual suicide, in the valorous House of Iyi. Kobayashi demonstrates his creative power and pure ingenuity in Harakiri as the story unfolds and he raises questions about honor, the Bushido code, the human condition, Samurai, the concept of power and how it affects those who wield it, and Japan's own identity as it emerges from the ever changing world of the post World War II period. Unlike other films about Japan's past and the Samurai in mainstream cinema, Harakiri questions the views of the Samurai and how they may have acted throughout history. For example, although "The Last Samurai" was well received in Japan, some viewers such as Tomomi Katsuta felt its honorable portrayal of the Samurai was incompatible with contemporary views, and that Japanese views of the Samurai are different, stating "Our image of Samurai is that they were more corrupt." For example, Samurai were permitted to kill common folk on site if they so much as gave them a dirty or disrespectful look. "Harakiri" does away with the fairy tale portrayals of Samurai that we often see, reflecting more of who they were and how power can corrupt all."Harakiri" will not disappoint, and I was pleasantly surprised with how it is capable of reaching all audiences, not just domestic ones. The fact that Kobayashi questions the human condition and how people of all origins sometimes handle power, honor, and cultural traditions, makes "Harakiri" and instant classic for anyone who watches it.

'Harakiri' goes from one conflict to the next very effectively. The movie is really a flashback, but shows the series of events that unfolded in a very linear fashion. Great fight scenes in this movie, and it's interesting to know that a lot of the fighting was done live with real weapons. The acting was played out very well with intensity in every character, as if most of their expressions could explain everything that was going on. I believe some of the long shots were a bit unnecessary and made the movie feel prolonged at points, but overall quite a bad-ass film portraying the eventual demise and corruption of Bushido code in the Samurai hierarchy.

If you're a fan of Japanese culture, and especially if you're into feudal Japanese samurai stuff, than Hara-kiri is a great film for you to watch. It's a Japanese made film from the 60's so don't expect a huge Hollywood type of movie, but even without all of the glamour, it's a very interesting movie filled with symbolism, eastern philosophy, dogma, and really makes you question culture in general and the codes we live by today.I felt like the way Kobayashi filmed the movie made it very suspenseful. At almost every moment it feels like there is some kind of tension going on, and that includes the dialogue which seemed to be most of the movie. Even with that in mind I feel the way it was filmed made every moment in the movie fun to watch. The actors where pretty good as well, especially the facial expressions in the close up shots and the real life sword fighting.A movie that I personally felt that had some similarities to Hara-kiri but in a more modern version was Rambo. Both Rambo and Hanshirō were soldiers who were dogmatic in their military ideology and fantastic soldiers. When they came back to society when they needed it most, they were treated like washed up dogs because society didn't need them anymore. Even though they were the ones whom the system created in the first place.

A brilliant showcase of well paced cinematic storytelling that will take you on an emotional ride of feeling anger, frustration, joy and sorrow. A true story about circumstances and the complexity of life.

Although i have experienced movies that have been influenced by the jidaigeki genre, never have I been exposed to one that was fully immersed into the world of samurais. Harakiri, from start to finish, had me at the edge of my seat. It was a guessing game at first, jumping to conclusions over what Motome's true intentions were and even applauding the Iyi Clan for "punishing" the imposter. That is until Hanshiro begins to tell his story... Kobayashi delivers his message loud and clear in such a subtle but powerful way that you are left thinking not only about the consequences of such dogmatic obsessions but also leaves you thinking about the master artistry that he and the actors devoted into the making of this film.
